title: Calm in the Chaos
author: Anonymous
content:
In the midst of a huge nowhere,
Chaos once reigns, wild and bare.
Where fighting is inevitable, raw and loud,
And nothing of value walks unbowed.

But within its darkness lay something still,
A space untouched by the world’s ill will.
Silence and calm, where truth holds tight,
Even as wrong screams loud in the night.

And within that something lays you,
A quiet queen with grace shining through.
Where home is peace, not frantic pace,
A steady light in a broken place.

Your presence weaves calm through storm and flame,
A whispered prayer, a sacred name.
You turn the mess to meaning deep,
And wake the lost from shattered sleep.

So while the world may tear and fall,
You stand unmoved, above it all.
The heart’s safe haven, soft and true—
This universe of calm begins with you.

title: Love at first sight
author: Anonymous
content:
I saw thee once, and in that glance,
The world did pause, as if by chance.
The air grew still, the heavens bent—
And beauty spoke with sweet intent.

Thine eyes, twin stars in twilight's sea,
Outshone the moon that looked on me.
A gaze that danced yet held me fast,
A fleeting look, forever cast.

Thy hair, like night with sun entwined,
Did tempt both art and poet’s mind.
Each strand a thread of gold’s pure grace,
Each breeze entranced to touch thy face.

Thy form, the shape of nature’s song,
Where every line did right no wrong.
A living sculpture, soft and bright,
The muse that haunts both dream and night.

Thy voice—ah, music's sweetest kin,
Did echo deep beneath my skin.
It called to me with siren's might,
And led my heart without a fight.

I fell not slow, but swift and sure,
No logic sought, no need to cure.
For what is man 'gainst beauty's flame,
But ash that gladly speaks her name?

And though time's tide may wash away,
The place I fell remains today.
For beauty such as thine imparts,
A mark eternal on men's hearts.

title: Why Thou Art Missing
author: Anonymous
content:
When thou art gone where duty lies,
And leave me 'neath the watching skies,
The sun grows dim, the air turns cold—
A tale of absence, softly told.

Thy place once filled with light and cheer
Now whispers low, 'She is not here.'
The air still holds thy vanished grace,
Yet longs in vain to see thy face.

In sacred halls where prayers ascend,
Thou art as flame the clouds attend.
I sit in hush and silent gaze,
While thou dost shine through holy praise.

Among the rows where souls do sing,
Thou movest like an angel's wing.
Yet though the hymn flows full and wide,
I feel the ache where thou dost bide.

And in the room where minds are fed,
Where thoughts are drawn and lectures led,
I find my eyes betray their task,
For where thou art is all I ask.

A glance, a turn, a fleeting grace—
It burns its shape in time and space.
And every step thou takest near,
Leaves echoes deep when thou'st not here.

So while the world may turn its page,
And hours pass in saint or sage,
Still doth my soul in quiet plea,
Await the hour thou return’st to me.

title: Gakos Tani
author: Anonymous
content:
Gakos tani ikaw subong,
Sa tunga sang ulan ukon adlaw nga mainit.
Indi na ko magpangita pa sang iban,
Basta ara ka lang, duol kag init.

Ginhawa ko naga hulat sang imo,
Kalma siya basta mahaplas mo ang likod ko.
Lipay siya basta matandog ko ang buhok mo,
Kag maghigda lang ta, wala sang plano.

Isa ka lang ka gakos, mabugnaw na ang adlaw,
Indi gid ya mabakal ni bisan sin-o.
Biskan ginakapoy ang kalibutan,
Nami gid ya ang pahway sa imo tupad.

Ginahandom ko ang imo dughan,
Bilang halik sang kalinong sa akon duta.
Sa imo dughan, ara ang puluy-an ko,
Wala sang kasakit nga makapalapit.

Pagduol mo palang gani,
Nagapadali na ang tagipusuon ko.
Abi ko bala may bomba nga gamay,
Pero halok lang gali sang gugma mo.

Tani karon pa lang, ara na ko dira,
Gapungko sa tupad mo nga tahimik lang.
Basi kapoy ka na sang tanan nga butang,
Ako na lang maggakos sa imo sang bug-os nga kalibutan.

Ikaw bala, ginabatyagan mo man?
Nga ako ya, halos magutok ang dughan.
Ginakulbaan ko kung indi mo mabatian,
Nga ginahandom ko ang init sang imo lawas.

Gakos tani ikaw, bisan wala ta pulong,
Kay ang lawas ta na ang nagahambal.
Sa isa ka gakos, ako nangin buhi,
Kag ang adlaw, indi na madulom liwat.

title: Mainit nga Gugma
author: Anonymous
content:
Sa imo lang gid ako nagahinay-hinay,
Sa tanang gab-i, damgo ikaw permi ang ginabay.
Mainit nga ginahandom, indi ko malikawan,
Lawas ko kag imo, daw pareho naga pangita-anay.

Ang panulok mo, kalayo sa tagipusuon,
Ginahingabot ako sang handum nga indi ko masugpon.
Kung maglapit ka, daw may ginabati nga kilat,
Ginapasipala ang kalinong, ginaguba sang gulat.

Gusto ko ikaw, indi lang sa hunahuna,
Kundi sa tanan nga butang nga pwede naton malukpan pa.
Ang palad mo sa akon panit, halong kag init,
Gina-uyatan ko ang hangin nga may dala nga pulong nga malipit.

Sa tunga sang pagpugong, may halong pagpadayon,
Duha ta ka lawas, ginapalibutan sang kahimtangan nga nagapungpong.
Indi kinahanglan sang pulong, ginabasa na ang mata,
Ang gugma ta, hilom pero puno sang balatyagon nga palapad nga katahum.

title: Gugma Ko Sa Imo
author: Anonymous
content:
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo mata nga nagasidlak,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo mga ngisi nga nagahatag sang kalipay.
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo mga buhok nga nagahuyop sa hangin,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo tingog nga nagapahamtang sang kalma sa akon.

Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo palanggaon nga panghunahuna,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo kamot nga mahumok kag mahigugmaon.
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo pagpalangga nga wala sang katapusan,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo mga damgo nga ginahandum ko man.

Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo pagkahamtong nga nagahatag sang kasiguraduhan,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo pagpalangga bisan sa mga kalisod.
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo katahum nga nagasiga pareho sang adlaw,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo pagtuo nga nagapabakod sang aton gugma.

Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo kahanginan nga nagahatag sang kinabuhi,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo mga halakhak nga nagapahilum sang kasubo.
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo pagpasensya kag pag-antos para sa aton,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa tanan nga ginahimo mo para sa akon kag sa aton.

Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo paghangop sang akon mga kahinaan,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo pagpakigbahin sang imo mga kalipay kag kasubo.
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo nga pagin kaupod ko sa tanan nga adlaw,
Palangga ko ikaw, sang sobra pa sa pulong nga mabutang ko.

Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo mga mata nga nagasugid sang mga tinago,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo dughan nga nagaduyog sang akon mga damgo.
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo pagsunod sang mga handum naton,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo nga pagpadayon bisan sang madamo nga pagsulay.

Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo halad nga gugma nga wala sang paglubad,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo mga hilikoton nga ginahimo para sa aton kalipay.
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo kabug-usan nga ginapakita sa akon adlaw-adlaw,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo kaugalingon nga ginapalangga ko gid.

Palangga ko ikaw, indi lang tungod sa imo mga kahimtang,
Palangga ko ikaw, kundi tungod ikaw ang ginahandom ko sa gihapon.
Palangga ko ikaw, bisan ano pa man ang matabo sa kalibutan,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa gihapon kag sa kadayunan.

Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo ngalan nga akon ginabatyagan,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo kahimtang nga ginahalinan sang akon paglaum.
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo paghigugma nga nagahatag sang kusog,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa tanan nga rason nga indi ko matandog.

Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo mga ginhawa nga ginahuyop ko sa dughan,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo presensya nga nagahatag sang kahulugan.
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo kalipay nga akon ginahalinan,
Palangga ko ikaw, nga ikaw lang ang ginahigugma ko sang tuman.

Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo mga pulong nga nagapalip-ot sang akon kalibutan,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo pag-ako sang akon mga sala kag kahuyang.
Palangga ko ikaw, sa imo nga nagapadayon sa pag-upod sa akon,
Palangga ko ikaw, sa gihapon, sa gihapon, kag sa gihapon.

title: Failing in Success
author: Anonymous
content:
We met in a game where falling was the rule,
A week to act like lovers, trying not to lose.
Falling step by step, pretending hearts would beat,
Two strangers playing parts, unsure if real or feat.

Day one was just a laugh, a tease in the air,
We joked and faked the closeness, caught unaware.
Day two brought quiet moments, sparks that wouldn’t fade,
Pretending felt too real, no longer just charade.

By day three, the game was done, we dropped the play,
From acting to believing, our hearts found their way.
No more just for a week, no rules to confine,
What started as a game, turned truly yours and mine.

We failed the game but won so much more,
In a world of pretending, we found the core.
From falling in a game to standing side by side,
A love unplanned, but one we can’t hide.

title: When You Are Old
author: W.B. Yeats
content:
When you are old and grey and full of sleep,
And nodding by the fire, take down this book,
And slowly read, and dream of the soft look
Your eyes had once, and of their shadows deep;

How many loved your moments of glad grace,
And loved your beauty with love false or true,
But one man loved the pilgrim soul in you,
And loved the sorrows of your changing face;

And bending down beside the glowing bars,
Murmur, a little sadly, how Love fled
And paced upon the mountains overhead
And hid his face amid a crowd of stars.

title: Variation on the Word Sleep
author: Margaret Atwood
content:
I would like to watch you sleeping,
which may not happen.
I would like to watch you,
sleeping. I would like to sleep
with you, to enter
your sleep as its smooth dark wave
slides over my head

and walk with you through that lucent
wavering forest of bluegreen leaves
with its watery sun & three moons
towards the cave where you must descend,
towards your worst fear

I would like to give you the silver
branch, the small white flower, the one
word that will protect you
from the grief at the center
of your dream, from the grief
at the center. I would like to follow
you up the long stairway
again & become
the boat that would row you back
carefully, a flame
in two cupped hands
to where your body lies
beside me, and you enter
it as easily as breathing in

I would like to be the air
that inhabits you for a moment
only. I would like to be that unnoticed
& that necessary.

title: The Good-Morrow
author: John Donne
content:
I wonder, by my troth, what thou and I
Did, till we loved? Were we not weaned till then?
But sucked on country pleasures, childishly?
Or snorted we in the Seven Sleepers' den?
'Twas so; but this, all pleasures fancies be.
If ever any beauty I did see,
Which I desired, and got, 'twas but a dream of thee.

And now good-morrow to our waking souls,
Which watch not one another out of fear;
For love, all love of other sights controls,
And makes one little room an everywhere.
Let sea-discoverers to new worlds have gone,
Let maps to other, worlds on worlds have shown,
Let us possess one world, each hath one, and is one.

My face in thine eye, thine in mine appears,
And true plain hearts do in the faces rest;
Where can we find two better hemispheres,
Without sharp north, without declining west?
Whatever dies, was not mixed equally;
If our two loves be one, or, thou and I
Love so alike, that none do slacken, none can die.

title: Valentine
author: Carol Ann Duffy
content:
Not a red rose or a satin heart.

I give you an onion.
It is a moon wrapped in brown paper.
It promises light
like the careful undressing of love.

Here.
It will blind you with tears
like a lover.
It will make your reflection
a wobbling photo of grief.

I am trying to be truthful.

Not a cute card or a kissogram.

I give you an onion.
Its fierce kiss will stay on your lips,
possessive and faithful
as we are,
for as long as we are.

Take it.
Its platinum loops shrink to a wedding-ring,
if you like.
Lethal.
Its scent will cling to your fingers,
cling to your knife.

title: The River-Merchant's Wife
author: Ezra Pound
content:
While my hair was still cut straight across my forehead
I played about the front gate, pulling flowers.
You came by on bamboo stilts, playing horse,
You walked about my seat, playing with blue plums.
And we went on living in the village of Chokan:
Two small people, without dislike or suspicion.

At fourteen I married My Lord you.
I never laughed, being bashful.
Lowering my head, I looked at the wall.
Called to, a thousand times, I never looked back.

At fifteen I stopped scowling,
I desired my dust to be mingled with yours
Forever and forever and forever.
Why should I climb the look out?

At sixteen you departed,
You went into far Ku-to-en, by the river of swirling eddies,
And you have been gone five months.
The monkeys make sorrowful noise overhead.

You dragged your feet when you went out.
By the gate now, the moss is grown, the different mosses,
Too deep to clear them away!
The leaves fall early this autumn, in wind.
The paired butterflies are already yellow with August
Over the grass in the West garden;
They hurt me. I grow older.
If you are coming down through the narrows of the river Kiang,
Please let me know beforehand,
And I will come out to meet you
As far as Cho-fu-Sa.

title: Bright Star
author: John Keats
content:
Bright star, would I were steadfast as thou art—
Not in lone splendour hung aloft the night
And watching, with eternal lids apart,
Like nature's patient, sleepless Eremite,
The moving waters at their priestlike task
Of pure ablution round earth's human shores,
Or gazing on the new soft-fallen mask
Of snow upon the mountains and the moors—
No—yet still steadfast, still unchangeable,
Pillowed upon my fair love's ripening breast,
To feel for ever its soft fall and swell,
Awake for ever in a sweet unrest,
Still, still to hear her tender-taken breath,
And so live ever—or else swoon to death.

title: Love After Love
author: Derek Walcott
content:
The time will come
when, with elation
you will greet yourself arriving
at your own door, in your own mirror
and each will smile at the other's welcome,

and say, sit here. Eat.
You will love again the stranger who was your self.
Give wine. Give bread. Give back your heart
to itself, to the stranger who has loved you

all your life, whom you ignored
for another, who knows you by heart.
Take down the love letters from the bookshelf,

the photographs, the desperate notes,
peel your own image from the mirror.
Sit. Feast on your life.

title: A Red, Red Rose
author: Robert Burns
content:
O my Luve is like a red, red rose
That's newly sprung in June;
O my Luve is like the melody
That's sweetly played in tune.

So fair art thou, my bonnie lass,
So deep in luve am I;
And I will luve thee still, my dear,
Till a' the seas gang dry.

Till a' the seas gang dry, my dear,
And the rocks melt wi' the sun;
I will love thee still, my dear,
While the sands o' life shall run.

And fare thee weel, my only luve!
And fare thee weel awhile!
And I will come again, my luve,
Though it were ten thousand mile.

title: The Passionate Shepherd to His Love
author: Christopher Marlowe
content:
Come live with me and be my love,
And we will all the pleasures prove,
That valleys, groves, hills, and fields,
Woods, or steepy mountain yields.

And we will sit upon the rocks,
Seeing the shepherds feed their flocks,
By shallow rivers to whose falls
Melodious birds sing madrigals.

And I will make thee beds of roses
And a thousand fragrant posies,
A cap of flowers, and a kirtle
Embroidered all with leaves of myrtle;

A gown made of the finest wool
Which from our pretty lambs we pull;
Fair lined slippers for the cold,
With buckles of the purest gold;

A belt of straw and ivy buds,
With coral clasps and amber studs:
And if these pleasures may thee move,
Come live with me, and be my love.

The shepherds' swains shall dance and sing
For thy delight each May morning:
If these delights thy mind may move,
Then live with me and be my love.

title: Meeting at Night
author: Robert Browning

title: Tonight I Can Write
author: Pablo Neruda
content:
Tonight I can write the saddest lines.

Write, for example, 'The night is starry
and the blue stars shiver in the distance.'

The night wind revolves in the sky and sings.

Tonight I can write the saddest lines.
I loved her, and sometimes she loved me too.

Through nights like this one I held her in my arms.
I kissed her again and again under the endless sky.

She loved me, sometimes I loved her too.
How could one not have loved her great still eyes.

Tonight I can write the saddest lines.
To think that I do not have her. To feel that I have lost her.

To hear the immense night, still more immense without her.
And the verse falls to the soul like dew to the pasture.

What does it matter that my love could not keep her.
The night is starry and she is not with me.

This is all. In the distance someone is singing. In the distance.
My soul is not satisfied that it has lost her.

My sight tries to find her as though to bring her closer.
My heart looks for her, and she is not with me.

The same night whitening the same trees.
We, of that time, are no longer the same.

I no longer love her, that's certain, but how I loved her.
My voice tried to find the wind to touch her hearing.

Another's. She will be another's. As she was before my kisses.
Her voice, her bright body. Her infinite eyes.

I no longer love her, that's certain, but maybe I love her.
Love is so short, forgetting is so long.

Because through nights like this one I held her in my arms
my soul is not satisfied that it has lost her.

Though this be the last pain that she makes me suffer
and these the last verses that I write for her.

title: somewhere i have never travelled
author: E.E. Cummings
content:
somewhere i have never travelled,gladly beyond
any experience,your eyes have their silence:
in your most frail gesture are things which enclose me,
or which i cannot touch because they are too near

your slightest look easily will unclose me
though i have closed myself as fingers,
you open always petal by petal myself as Spring opens
(touching skilfully,mysteriously)her first rose

or if your wish be to close me, i and
my life will shut very beautifully ,suddenly,
as when the heart of this flower imagines
the snow carefully everywhere descending;

nothing which we are to perceive in this world equals
the power of your intense fragility:whose texture
compels me with the color of its countries,
rendering death and forever with each breathing

(i do not know what it is about you that closes
and opens;only something in me understands
the voice of your eyes is deeper than all roses)
nobody,not even the rain,has such small hands

title: Having a Coke with You
author: Frank O'Hara
content:
is even more fun than going to San Sebastian, Irún, Hendaye, Biarritz, Bayonne
or being sick to my stomach on the Travesera de Gracia in Barcelona
partly because in your orange shirt you look like a better happier St. Sebastian
partly because of my love for you, partly because of your love for yoghurt
partly because of the fluorescent orange tulips around the birches
partly because of the secrecy our smiles take on before people and statuary
it is hard to believe when I'm with you that there can be anything as still
as solemn as unpleasantly definitive as statuary when right in front of it
in the warm New York 4 o'clock light we are drifting back and forth
between each other like a tree breathing through its spectacles

and the portrait show seems to have no faces in it at all, just paint
you suddenly wonder why in the world anyone ever did them

I look
at you and I would rather look at you than all the portraits in the world
except possibly for the Polish Rider occasionally and anyway it's in the Frick
which thank heavens you haven't gone to yet so we can go together the first time
and the fact that you move so beautifully more or less takes care of Futurism
just as at home I never think of the Nude Descending a Staircase or
at a rehearsal a single drawing of Leonardo or Michelangelo that used to wow me
and what good does all the research of the Impressionists do them
when they never got the right person to stand near the tree when the sun sank
or for that matter Marino Marini when he didn't pick the rider as carefully
as the horse

it seems they were all cheated of some marvellous experience
which is not going to go wasted on me which is why I am telling you about it
